Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Genetic diversity, resistance genes, and negative density dependence in tropical tree seedling dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Tropical forests are famous for their high diversity, as well as the large number of rare species they harbor. Recent studies have found that, compared to common species, rare tropical tree species suffer more from pathogens that are specialized to a single host species that then spread rapidly through dense patches of seedlings of that single host. This research will test the novel hypothesis that rare species are more strongly impacted by host-specific pathogens because they have lower diversity of resistance genes at the population level, such that all their seedlings will be susceptible to the same suite of pathogens, promoting rapid pathogen spread and increasing mortality rates. This hypothesis will be tested using experimental greenhouse and field studies, combined with genetic analyses that will quantify the diversity of resistance genes for rare and common tree species in lowland tropical forest on Barro Colorado Island, Panama. Computer simulations will also be used to examine whether the measured differences in resistance gene diversity would impact infection levels, mortality rates and local abundance of tree species. Results of this study will improve understanding of plant-pathogen interactions, with potential applications for agriculture and horticulture (e.g. increasing pathogen resistance in crops). Hands-on training in cutting-edge genetic techniques would be provided to a wider audience through a summer workshop for students and faculty.

This study will be the first to obtain large transcriptome datasets from a tree community and will provide gene sequence data that will be informative for future studies of genetic diversity in tropical forests. Examination of the effects of resistance gene diversity on forest dynamics will bridge the gap between molecular evolution studies that indicate ongoing selection for multiple resistance genes at many loci, and how this diversity functions in nature. Furthermore, this study is likely to bridge competing theories for tropical plant diversity by providing a genetic explanation for why rare tree species are more strongly controlled by their species-specific enemies, while simultaneously supporting dispersal limitation as a feature determining which species are locally dominant. Ultimately, the study should elucidate whether local rarity restricts local genetic diversity, which in turn reinforces local rarity, a cycle that can be escaped only by recruitment of new alleles via long-distance pollen or seed movement. Demonstrating such a coupling between the ecological and genetic features of populations would bring new perspectives and avenues for theoretical advances in evolution and ecology. The project will provide research experiences for undergraduate and graduate students, as well as a postdoctoral researcher.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tropical forests have attracted biologists world-wide to study the incredibly high species diversity of tropical plants and animals. One big question that remains largely unanswered is, what are the processes that allow for so many tropical plant species to coexist in a small area, especially those that are rare in abundance? Although many potential explanations have been investigated, one leading mechanisms is that negative feedbacks between trees and specialized enemies prevent competitively dominant tree species from forcing rare species to local extinction. This could occur if adult trees harbor specialized pathogens that attack their own offspring relative to offspring of other species. Previous experimental and observational studies in Panama have found that tree species are suppressed by their own specialized root-associated microbes (exhibit negative feedback) or do more poorly when surrounded by trees of the same species (exhibit negative density dependence). Importantly, these studies also reveal that the degree of susceptibility to their own enemies differs among tree species, where rare species are suppressed more than common species. Therefore pathogen-mediated feedbacks could serve as a strong force in maintaining the high diversity of tree species, as well as determining why some tree species are common, while the majority of other species are rare.  

 We built off of these findings and explicitly tested the genetic underpinnings as to why some tree species are more vulnerable to their own root-associated enemies than other tree species. We hypothesized that rare tree species would have lower allelic diversity of pathogen-resistance (R) genes due to a limited number of pollen donors. If so, then seedlings of rare tree species of low R gene diversity would be more susceptible to the same suites of pathogens, whereas escape from pathogen attack would occur in species exhibiting higher R gene diversity. Using greenhouse experiments, we also tested the degree to which pathogen susceptibility is specialized, both at the level of species, and at the level genotype.  

Consistent with our hypothesis, our genomic analyses found that rare tree species had lower allelic R gene diversitythan do more common species. Further, tree species with lower R gene diversity suffered more from the effects of their own root-associated microbes in the greenhouse, and to higher densities conspecific seedlings in the field. We also found evidence suggesting genotypic specialization of both root-associated pathogens and mutualists. In one tree species, Virola surinamensis, we found that seedlings suffered more when in soil from maternal trees than from nonmaternal trees. However, in a follow-up greenhouse study across a wider range tree species, we found the opposite pattern where seedlings were promoted by root-associated microbes from their maternal conspecific trees, suggesting a stronger role of genotype-specific soil mutualists such as arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi. Seedlings grown with soils from nonmaternal conspecifics still performed worse than with soils from other trees species, a pattern required for species coexistence.  

These experiments highlight the interplay between detrimental and beneficial soil-borne microbes, where for some tree species the negative effects of genotype-specialized pathogens may dominate, whereas in other species the positive effects of genotype-specialized mutualists dominate. The implications for this level of specialization to species coexistence is being explored by computer modeling. Thus far, we have found that genotypic-specialization of pathogens can maintain coexistence, but not as strongly as pathogens that only specialize at the species level.  How such specialization with mutualists influence this interpretation is now being tested.   

 Our study was the first massive effort to apply genomic techniques to understand the implications of plant-pathogen interactions to the assembly of tropical forests. We now have a large library of functional gene sequences that could extend our understanding of plant-pathogen interactions in other systems and be used in other applications, including agriculture and human health. Funds for this portion of the collaborative award were used to train and mentor 4 Panamanian students and technicians, and provided tropical field experience for 2 female undergraduates from Washington University in St. Louis.
